importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Retail coffee prices jumped nearly 21% in August 2025 compared to the same month in 2024, indicating a significant price surge driven by tariffs and rising import costs.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from July to September 2025 saw the introduction of new tariffs on coffee imports from Brazil, Vietnam, and Colombia, leading to increased costs for roasters and consumers.

keyTakeAways: The U.S. imports over 99% of its coffee, with Brazil supplying 30.7% of imports, Colombia 18.3%, and Vietnam 6.6%.
Trump administration tariffs imposed on coffee imports — 50% on Brazil, 20% on Vietnam, and 10% on Colombia — have significantly increased production costs for roasters.
The average price of a restaurant coffee in August 2025 rose to $3.52, up 10 cents from the previous year.
In Washington, D.C., a regular hot coffee averaged $4.21 in August 2025 (up 4%) and cold brew averaged $5.35 (up 3.7%).

Roasters such as Swing’s Coffee Roasters, Vigilante Coffee Company, and Celtic Cup Coffee Roasting report increased costs due to tariffs and supply chain issues, leading to higher prices for consumers.
Owners of specialty coffee businesses face uncertainty due to unpredictable pricing and import costs, with some considering diversification of bean sources to mitigate risks.
A bipartisan 'No Coffee Tax Act' was introduced in September 2025 by Rep. Don Bacon (Nebraska) and Rep. Ro Khanna (California) to exempt coffee products from tariffs.
Consumers may shift brands, look for deals, or reduce perceived quality to save money, but coffee remains an affordable luxury and consumption habits are unlikely to change drastically.

namedEntities.name: Trump administration
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A government body responsible for implementing trade policies
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Trump administration imposed tariffs on coffee imports, directly increasing costs for U.S. roasters and consumers.

namedEntities.name: Brazil
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A country that is the top coffee exporter to the U.S.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Brazil supplies 30.7% of U.S. coffee imports and was hit with a 50% tariff, making it the most affected country in terms of supply and cost.

namedEntities.name: Vietnam
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A coffee-exporting country with significant U.S. market presence
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Vietnam supplies 6.6% of U.S. coffee imports and faces a 20% tariff, contributing to increased import costs.

namedEntities.name: Colombia
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A coffee-exporting nation supplying a portion of U.S. coffee imports
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Colombia supplies 18.3% of U.S. coffee imports and faces a 10% tariff, adding to the overall cost burden on roasters.

namedEntities.name: Swing’s Coffee Roasters
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A coffee roaster with locations in Virginia and Washington, D.C.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Swing’s Coffee Roasters has reported increased costs due to tariffs and environmental factors, leading to higher prices for consumers.

namedEntities.name: Vigilante Coffee Company
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A coffee roaster with locations in California and Maryland
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Vigilante Coffee Company imports beans from Brazil, Indonesia, Ethiopia, and Colombia and has seen price increases of up to 50 cents per 12-ounce bag due to tariffs and supply issues.

namedEntities.name: Celtic Cup Coffee Roasting
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A coffee roaster based in Silver Spring, Maryland
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Celtic Cup Coffee Roasting avoids Brazilian coffee due to high tariffs and has observed a rise in bean costs of about 63 cents per pound since January 2025.

namedEntities.name: Qualia Coffee
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A specialty coffee business selling at farmers’ markets in Washington, D.C.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Qualia Coffee owner Joel Finkelstein expresses concern over pricing uncertainty, making long-term business planning difficult.

namedEntities.name: Don Bacon
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Rep. Don Bacon co-introduced the bipartisan 'No Coffee Tax Act' in September 2025 to exempt coffee from tariffs.

namedEntities.name: Ro Khanna
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Rep. Ro Khanna co-introduced the bipartisan 'No Coffee Tax Act' in September 2025 to exempt coffee from tariffs.

namedEntities.name: Toast
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Toast provided data showing a 21% increase in coffee prices in August 2025 and price trends in Washington, D.C. restaurants.

namedEntities.name: National Coffee Association
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A U.S. trade association representing coffee industry stakeholders
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The National Coffee Association reported that the U.S. imports over 99% of its coffee, highlighting the nation’s reliance on global supply chains.

namedEntities.name: Conference Board
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Conference Board provided economic analysis on consumer behavior in response to rising coffee prices.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Trump administration's imposition of steep tariffs—50% on Brazil, 20% on Vietnam, and 10% on Colombia—has significantly increased the cost of imported coffee beans, leading to price hikes for roasters and consumers. With the U.S. importing over 99% of its coffee, most of it from Brazil, Colombia, and Vietnam, businesses like Swing’s Coffee Roasters, Vigilante Coffee Company, and Celtic Cup Coffee Roasting are struggling with rising bean costs and supply chain disruptions. These cost increases have led to higher prices for coffee in restaurants and cafes, such as a 21% average price increase in August 2025. Consumers are reacting by changing brands or seeking deals, but coffee remains an affordable luxury and consumption habits are not expected to shift dramatically. In response, bipartisan lawmakers like Rep. Don Bacon and Rep. Ro Khanna have introduced the 'No Coffee Tax Act' to exempt coffee products from tariffs. Despite growing uncertainty, roasters are exploring diversification of bean sources to maintain affordability and market stability.
title: Trump’s Tariffs Are Brewing Trouble for Coffee Roasters
